image.altText: Former NRL player Jarryd Hayne looking unhappy in a street

items.synopsis: The former NRL player remarked 'say no more' after the judge read out his sentence for the 2018 sexual assault in Newcastle.

image.altText: Peter Dutton sits in the House of Representatives

image.altText: Peter Hollingworth

title.children: Peter Hollingworth says he will no longer officiate as Anglican priest after church investigation finding

image.altText: Lara Alexander and John Tucker looking at each other.

items.synopsis: Concerns over a contentious $715 million stadium and the government's priorities have pushed two Tasmanian MPs to quit the Liberal Party and sit as independents, ending Premier Jeremy Rockliff's majority.

title.children: Anger over Hobart AFL stadium sinks Tasmania's government into minority as MPs quit party

image.altText: John Pesutto and Moira Deeming in a composite image.

items.synopsis: Rebel Victorian MP Moira Deeming has been expelled from the parliamentary Liberal Party after a meeting of MPs this morning, with Renee Heath ditched as partyroom secretary.

title.children: Victorian Liberal leader labels expulsion of MP Moira Deeming a 'turning point' in party's reform

image.altText: Domenic Perre pictured during the 1990s, with slicked back hair, a patterned blue shirt and aviator shades

items.synopsis: The family of Domenic Perre, who died earlier this week less than a year after he was convicted of murdering a detective inÂ the 1994 NCA bombing, is considering making a petition for mercy.

title.children: Ellie Price murder trial abandoned for a second time after new evidence emerges

image.altText: People walk through the front door of a house, past a For Lease sign.

title.children: 'We need intervention': Renters say price caps are needed to help keep a roof over their heads

image.altText: A teenage girl in sports gear concentrates as she grasps and swings between two "X"-shaped plates hanging from the ceiling.

title.children: Teenager Abbey Cutts practices for hours on a ninja course in her backyard. Now she's heading to world finals

image.altText: Jeremy Rockliff appears to be in thought, surrounded by his colleagues.

items.synopsis: Just yesterday, the TasmanianÂ government was sailing along relatively smoothly as the only remaining Liberal government inÂ the country, but two bombshell resignations have changed all that, writes Adam Langenberg.

title.children: The Tasmanian premier's $715 million stadium is costing him more than money

image.altText: A man with a backwards cap holding a football.

items.synopsis: Daniel Hayes was forging a path to a dream career in the AFL 17 years ago â but after leaving the Demons without playing a game, the small forward was left grappling with feelings few understood.

title.children: When Daniel Hayes disappeared from the AFL, he didn't share his pain â now he is suing his junior coach

image.altText: Soldiers launch missiles hidden by camouflage tents and surrounded by trees

title.children: Russia denies reports of Ukrainian breakthroughs along frontlines near Bakhmut

image.altText: A man sitting behind a desk, leaning back in his chair and scratching his chin, mid-conversation.

items.synopsis: Michael Gunner has been cleared of alleged political interference over the decision to charge former Northern Territory police officer Zachary Rolfe with the murder of Kumanjayi Walker.

title.children: Former chief minister cleared of alleged political interference in Rolfe murder charge

image.altText: Yatala Labour Prison

items.synopsis: The South Australian Deputy Coroner finds there were a "litany of serious failings and shortcomings" in how a first-time Aboriginal inmate was managed in the state's highest security prison and inÂ police cells, where conditions wereÂ "barbaric and inhumane".

title.children: Aboriginal inmate kept in 'barbaric and inhumane' conditions before death in custody, inquest finds

image.altText: Frank Hu holds a phone to his ear, dressed in a green jumper.

items.synopsis: A serial rapist will spend decades behind bars for spiking the drinks of female colleagues, sexually abusing them while they were passed out and posting images of the attacks online.

title.children: Man who offered female colleagues drugged drinks before raping them jailed for 'cold, calculated' attacks

image.altText: Short sleeved dark navy police t-shirt, viewed from back of officer in uniform

items.synopsis: Emergency services were contactedÂ when a visiting relative attempted to see the man and was allegedly told he was in hospital.

title.children: 'Mummified' body found in Gold Coast home where two people lived

image.altText: Two people standing in front of a pizza store, with the logo visible in the background.

items.synopsis: The manager of a regional Victorian pizza shop is calling outÂ racism after several incidents which she believes targeted Pakistani staff.

title.children: 'This is their home': Takeaway worker's call to stand up against racism

image.altText: Former president Donald Trump claps his hand together at rally in Manchester, New Hampshire.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump signals he will appeal against a jury's decision to find him liable for sexualÂ abuse and defamation, a day after joking about the case during a controversial CNN broadcast.Â

title.children: Trump lodges appeal against sexual abuse finding as CNN grapples with town hall fallout

image.altText: Peter Dutton Budget reply

items.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says JobSeeker recipients should be allowed to work more hours without it eating into their payments, as he responds to the federal budget.Â

title.children: Dutton says JobSeeker recipients should be allowed to work more instead of having payments increased

image.altText: Composite image ofÂ Carlos Alcaraz and Aryna Sabalenka with birthday cakes presented to them at the Madrid Open.

items.synopsis: The chief executive of the Madrid Open apologises after the women's doubles finalists were not allowed to address fans after their match and saysÂ it will never happen again, but the tournament is under fire for other issues regarding inequality.

title.children: 'Couldn't be more accurate': What two birthday cakes say about top tennis tournament's treatment of women

image.altText: A woman stands with a handwritten sign in front of a crowd in Federation Square.

items.synopsis: Members of the Pakistani diaspora, chantingÂ "this terrorism has a uniform behind it", protestÂ in Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne following the arrest of former prime minister Imran Khan in Islamabad this week.

title.children: Imran Khan's Australian supporters take to the streets to denounce military and 'injustice'

image.altText: A group of people is pictured sitting on trop of a train, some have their legs hanging over the side.

items.synopsis: Thousands of migrants in Mexico have been clambering onto dangerous freight trains rumbling northward in a scramble to reach the USÂ border by the time the United States ends a tough migration policy.

title.children: Migrants risk life and limb to jump Mexico trains in rush to US border as Title 42 draws to an end

image.altText: A man sings while sitting in a car with the headlights on, on stage during rehearsals for the Eurovision Song Contest.

items.synopsis: For the past eight years, Australia has been welcomed into the glitter-lacedÂ arms of Eurovision, but this mayÂ come to an end very soon.

title.children: This could be our last year competing in Eurovision, but why is Australia in Eurovision in the first place?

image.altText: An open cut mine pit at Burton coal mine near Moranbah.

items.synopsis: The Isaac River Mine in central Queensland has been flagged for approval if a vulnerable snake can be protected, but an environmental group says people who voted in favour of climate action have a right to feel betrayed.Â

title.children: 'A right to feel betrayed': New coal mine flagged for approval by federal government

image.altText: Craig Kelly in a yellow hat.

items.synopsis: United Australia Party national director Craig Kelly says the TGA 'surrendered" on antiparasitic drug ivermectin with its decision to allow off-label prescription once again. But what actually happened?

title.children: Former Liberal MP Craig Kelly claims the TGA has 'surrendered' on ivermectin. Is that correct?

image.altText: Leila De Lima wearing a mask waves amid a crowd of people.

items.synopsis: Leila De Lima âÂ one of the fiercest critics of former president Rodrigo Duterte âÂ is acquitted of aÂ criminal charge stemming from allegations that, as a cabinet minister, she received money from drug dealers.

title.children: Philippine court acquits former senator who launched inquiry into Rodrigo Duterte's 'war on drugs'

image.altText: The ASX close to steady in early trade as seen on the exchange's board at its Sydney office

items.synopsis: Falls across most of the resources sector and a big drop for QBE on its latest earnings update are weighing the ASX down in morning trade.Â Stay acrossÂ the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.Â

title.children: ASX weighed down by QBE earnings update, mining sell-off

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As we approach the mid-point of the trading day, the ASX is still posting very moderate losses. The benchmark ASX 200 index was down 0.2% at 7,240 points at 12:33pm AEST, while the broader All Ords was also off 0.2% at 7,436. As in early trade, it is the resources sector letting down the market, with both miners and energy companies losing ground. Basic materials (mostly mining) was down 1.4% and energy was off 1.2%. Every other sector was up, but this is Australia, and half of our corporate profits come from resource extraction, so where the miners go, often the market goes. Education and healthcare were still the biggest gainers. The best performers around 12:35pm were: Lake Resources: +8.7% to $0.625 Graincorp: +5.3% to $8.225 BrainChip Holdings: +4.6% to $0.46 News Corp: +4.5% to $25.92 Nanosonics: +2.8% to $5.55 The worst performers were: Sandfire Resources: -6% to $6.11 Regis Resources: -5.4% to $2.035 Evolution Mining: -5% to $3.685 West African Resources: -4.1% to $0.935 De Grey Mining: -3.9% to $1.4325
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX remains slightly in the red by the middle of the trading session

children.content: As we approach the mid-point of the trading day, the ASX is still posting very moderate losses.
The benchmark ASX 200 index was down 0.2% at 7,240 points at 12:33pm AEST, while the broader All Ords was also off 0.2% at 7,436.
As in early trade, it is the resources sector letting down the market, with both miners and energy companies losing ground.
Basic materials (mostly mining) was down 1.4% and energy was off 1.2%.
Every other sector was up, but this is Australia, and half of our corporate profits come from resource extraction, so where the miners go, often the market goes.
Education and healthcare were still the biggest gainers.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This short statement out today from Medibank: "Late on 11 May 2023, the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) advised Medibank that it has decided to proceed with the investigation of the representative complaint lodged by Maurice Blackburn on 18 November 2022. "The OAIC advised it will proceed with the investigation of the representative complaint at the same time as the Commissioner's own investigation. "Medibank continues to support its customers from the impact of the cybercrime through our previously announced Cyber Response Support Program which includes mental health and wellbeing support, identity protection and financial hardship measures." This is some further context of the legal actions underway against Medibank over the data breach, with Slater and Gordon last week also announcing a class action .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Medibank facing privacy breach investigation as customers seek compensation

featuredLink.title: Class action firms join forces to litigate Medibank breach

children.content: This short statement out today from Medibank:

"Late on 11 May 2023, the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) advised Medibank that it has decided to proceed with the investigation of the representative complaint lodged by Maurice Blackburn on 18 November 2022.
"The OAIC advised it will proceed with the investigation of the representative complaint at the same time as the Commissioner's own investigation.

"Medibank continues to support its customers from the impact of the cybercrime through our previously announced Cyber Response Support Program which includes mental health and wellbeing support, identity protection and financial hardship measures."
This is some further context of the legal actions underway against Medibank over the data breach, with
Slater and Gordon last week also announcing a class action

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As indicated by the futures market, it's a pretty flat start to trade on the ASX. The ASX 200 was up 1 point at 7,253 around 10:15am AEST â that's point, not per cent â and the All Ords was down 2 points at 7,448. Most companies in the top 200 were doing well, with 131 in the black and only 65 in the red. But the mining sector, notably the big iron ore miners, were among those losing ground, weighing on the index as a whole. BHP (-1.7%), Rio Tinto (-1.4%) and Fortescue (-1.6%) were all down after spot iron ore prices dropped below $US100 a tonne, continuing recent trends on signs of Chinese economic weakness. QBE was another big company dragging on the market â investors clearly not impressed with its first quarter performance update, despite 11% growth in gross written premium. The company did warn about the cost of a number of natural disasters, which is already creeping towards its first half catastrophe allowance with a couple of months yet to go. QBE shares were down 5.1 per cent to $14.39. Healthcare, education and consumer cyclicals were today's leading sectors, with energy joining mining as the laggards. The big four banks were up between 0.2 and 1 per cent, with Westpac leading. Five biggest gains on ASX 200: News Corp: +4.1% to $25.81 GrainCorp: +2.6% to $8.015 Sayona Mining: +2.4% to $0.215 Imugene: +2.1% to $0.1225 Polynovo: +1.6% to $1.4125 Five biggest losses on ASX 200: Sandfire Resources: -5.2% to $6.16 QBE Insurance: -4.8% to $14.43 Champion Iron: -3.7% to $6.20 Regis Resources: -3.7% to $2.07 Paladin Energy: -3.7% to $0.66
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Miners, QBE weigh on ASX in early trade

items.synopsis: A major supplier of frozen rodents has decreased shipments to WA, reducing the supply for pet snakes and reptilesÂ and forcing up costsÂ at smaller pet shops.

title.children: Frozen rodent shortage leaves WA pet reptiles 'emaciated' and owners 'desperate'

image.altText: A composite image of the headless ram and the updated version.

items.synopsis: The tiny town of Narrawong was shocked when aÂ mighty wooden ram that guards the district was callously decapitated in February. Then Chainsaw Kev came to the rescue.Â

title.children: How 'Chainsaw Kev' came out of the woodwork to fix south-west Victoria's decapitated ram sculpture

image.altText: Three men and their avocados.

items.synopsis: Tucked into the lush highlands west of Cairns is northern Australia's largest rural population, and it's booming again with agriculture seemingly the primary catalyst.Â Â

title.children: Fruit and veg is driving northern Australia's largest rural population to grow even bigger
